Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The role of species dominance in mediating biodiversity-ecosystem function relationships across spatial scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecosystem services, or the benefits that nature delivers to people, include many functions essential to life on earth such as carbon storage, water purification, and pollination. Two decades of ecological experiments and theory have clearly demonstrated that biodiversity plays an important role in ecosystem functioning, such that biological communities containing more species have higher levels of ecosystem function. However, virtually all of this research has been conducted at small scales and under experimentally controlled conditions that may not represent real-world ecosystems. This project will bridge the gap between the extensive knowledge scientists have developed about the biodiversity-ecosystem function relationship at smaller experimental scales, and the largely unknown role of biodiversity in driving ecosystem services at the scale of real-world landscapes. The researchers will study the pollination delivered to native wildflowers by wild insect pollinators, to determine how many pollinator species are required to provide sufficient pollination to all study sites as spatial scale increases from a single plant community to an entire landscape. Specifically, they will test contrasting predictions about how the number of species required to provide adequate ecosystem services in the real world could be either more, or fewer, than that found in experiments. The results of this study will have important applications for the management of ecosystem services as well as for biodiversity conservation.

This will be the first study to investigate how two well-known features of communities, turnover in species composition across space, and species dominance (the prevalence of a few common species and many rare ones), jointly determine the importance of biodiversity to ecosystem services at real-world scales. In order to measure real-world complexity while simultaneously controlling real-world noise, the researchers will use experimental, multi-species arrays of native plants placed throughout a 1600 km2 area as a standardized method for sampling wild pollinator communities and the pollination function they provide. Rarefaction models will be used to determine how the number of pollinator species that are important to pollination changes with increasing spatial scale, and null models will be used to remove, and thus quantify, the effect of dominance relative to that of species turnover.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

 

The role of biodiversity in providing ecosystem services such as carbon storage, water filtration, and pollination has rarely been studied at large spatial scales. In this project, the researchers conducted a large-scale field experiment in which they measured the pollination provided by native bee communities across a 400 km2 area. They found that the number of bee species needed to pollinate crops and wild plants increases by an order of magnitude when many (up to 48) sites are considered, as compared with a single site (Winfree et al. 2019, Science 359:791). In addition to analyzing their own data, the researchers did a comparative analysis of publicly available data measuring the importance of biodiversity to ecosystem services in smaller-scale experiments, as compared with large-scale, real world systems. They found that ecosystem services are less dependent on biodiversity in nature, as compared with experiments, due to several features of natural communities that are not well captured by experiments (Genung et al. 2020, Global Ecology and Biogeography 29:1531). These project outcomes help to reconcile the conflicting results found in previous studies, and to build an evidence-based understanding of how biodiversity affects ecosystem services in the real world.

 

Broader Impacts

Using the data collected under this and other grants, the researchers developed the first assessment of rarity for most of the ~400 bee species native to New Jersey. They worked with the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection to incorporate this information into the State Wildlife Action Plan, which is the necessary precursor step enabling legislative protection of rare species at the State level. Many of the bee species that are rare were also found to be important crop pollinators in the research conducted under this grant. Thus, this broader impact will extend the research results into protection of species that are important to food security. Three REU students were mentored by the researchers, including a Black woman and a Hispanic woman, both of whom are first-generation college students. All REU students presented their research at the Ecological Society of America meeting, which is the premier national meeting for the field of ecology, with their travel to the meeting supported by the grant.
